name: Dialogues with Books: Monthly Meetup
description: Join Bangalore`s Iconic Book Community - Monthly DWB Meetup! 📚Join Dialogues with Books (DWB) for our monthly gathering where fellow bibliophiles come together to celebrate the joy of reading!What We`ll Do -Come with a book you`ve been enjoying lately - any genre welcome! We`ll all share what we`re reading, why it resonates with us, and dive into lively discussions about the stories and ideas that captivate us. Feel free to read favourite passages aloud and discover your next great read through fellow bibliophiles` recommendations.Expect an evening of engaging book conversations over warm beverages, light snacks, and great company!About DWB - Dialogues with Books is one of Bangalore`s oldest book communities, creating a vibrant, inclusive space where literature lovers share their passion and form lasting friendships through books. Whether you`re a seasoned reader or looking to reconnect with reading, you`ll find a warm welcome here.DWB is Perfect For: Book enthusiasts, readers wanting to discover new genres, and anyone seeking thoughtful literary conversations in Bangalore`s vibrant reading community.Location: Dialogues KoramangalaMeet Your Host: Bharat - Bharat is an avid reader, writer, and passionate bibliophile with eclectic literary tastes spanning classics, fiction, philosophy, poetry, and self-improvement. His favorite authors include Hemingway, Murakami, Mishima, P.G. Wodehouse, and Edgar Allan Poe. His infectious enthusiasm for books and skill at facilitating discussions makes every meetup both stimulating and enjoyable.

name: Food In Literature Book Club
description: Our emotions and memories are intrinsically related to the food we eat and the genre of foodliterature combines them in a way that helps us connect not only to our past and our present, to different cultures, and communities, values and rituals, events both life-changing and mundane but to each other as well. So, if viewing the world through the lens of food and literature interests you, then join us for a dialogue on “Food in Literature” and to celebrate those stories and their diversity. Each month with Prachi Grover, we read our way through several powerful (and delicious) narratives.February Read: The Food of Paradise by Khalid JawedWe assure you that you will enjoy every single bite!The session is free but registration is a must as we have limited spots available. Prachi Grover is a culinary consultant and educator and is the founder of “From Words to Wok”; a community for people who to love to read and eat!When: Saturday, 28th February, 2026 at 11 a.m.Where: Atta Galatta Bookstore, Indira NagarAges: 18+Registration is mandatory (link in bio)Copies of the book are available at the store.

name: Dinner with strangers by StepOut (Bengaluru)
description: Serendipity on a TableStepOut Dinners bring strangers together at some of the city’s best restaurants for an evening that feels easy, warm, and unexpectedly meaningful.You are seated at a small, thoughtfully curated table with people you would likely never meet otherwise. Different backgrounds, different stories, one shared meal. The crowd is balanced, open minded, and there by choice, not chance. No loud networking. No awkward icebreakers. Just good food, unforced conversations, and the kind of listening that rarely happens in daily life.The restaurants are carefully chosen. Comfortable, well loved spaces where you can settle in and talk without rushing. The focus is not on the menu alone, but on the atmosphere that allows connection to unfold naturally.Some nights are light and playful. Some go deeper than expected. Some surprise you quietly. That is the point.StepOut Dinners are not about dating or outcomes. They are about discovery. Showing up. Sitting down. Letting the table do its quiet work.Sometimes, all it takes is one seat at the right table for life to feel a little more open. For more information, visit www.stepout.world

description: Turtle Forum is 3-day residential bootcamp (23–25 April, Bengaluru) designed for development practitioners working on social media, communications, and fundraising. name: Japanese Kintsugi
description: Join the exclusive Japanese Kintsugi workshop by Aabha.A 500-year-old Japanese art form, Kintsugi teaches us to mend broken pieces with gold, honouring cracks instead of hiding them. Rooted in the philosophy of wabi-sabi, it celebrates imperfection, resilience, and the beauty of transformation, where what was once broken becomes more valuable than before.In this hands-on workshop, you’ll experience the quiet meditative process of repairing ceramics, learning how restoration itself can become an art and a gentle reminder that flaws tell stories worth preserving.

name: Coffee with the boys
description: Coffee with the BoysBy Fight Club × 301 Coffee CornerCoffee with the Boys is a slow, intentional experience by Fight Club, in collaboration with 301 Coffee Corner (Avinash & Lily), hosted at Bunco HQ. It’s an afternoon to pause and connect, using good coffee as the anchor for conversations around men’s mental health, community, and third spaces.What to ExpectWe begin with a short introduction from the hosts and the coffee team and understand their why coffee, the nostalgia, ritual, and sensory grounding. A brief on the story behind 301 Coffee Corner with a quick intro round + your relationship with coffee Then we set context on: Where coffee comes from Types of beans and key terms Farm → roastery → brew → table What we’ll be brewing and why Live demonstration of the brewing methods (Coffee plan and flow may be adapted by the hosts.)The Fight Club Sit-DownFight Club Sit-Down Once the coffee is poured, we shift focus to slowing down. We move into a guided Fight Club conversation, grounded, honest, and relaxed. Just people in a room, sharing perspectives, listening, and noticing how rituals like coffee become third spaces, places where men can show up with curiosity.Brewing SessionFor those curious, the coffee team will open up a hands-on brewing session.You can learn the method, ask questions, get involved, or simply sip, observe, and connect at your own pace.After the SessionThe space remains open for lunch at Bunco (optional, at your own cost).Bunco warmly welcomes you to stay back, continue brewing, talking, or simply enjoy good food and company.Come for the coffee. Stay for the conversation. Leave with both.Event Details📍 Venue: Bunco HQ, Vasuda Enclave, Doddanekundi, Mahadevapura, Bengaluru🗓 Date: Saturday, 28 February 2026⏰ Time: 10:00 AM to 12:30 PMNoteFight Club is a non-profit social impact organisation.All costs collected go toward sustaining our work.Bunco HQ is generously hosting us at no cost, and we are grateful for their support.

name: The Prophet and the Poet
description: About the play:The Prophet and the Poet is based on the exchange of letters and articles between Mahatma Gandhi and Rabindranath Tagore over 25 years, with the Indian freedom struggle as the backdrop. The letters reveal how the two personalities differed significantly on the form and content of the freedom movement. The differences widened over the years. However, the depth of their personalities maintained genuine respect for each other in spite of deep differences on ideological grounds. It reflected the political maturity of those times in India. Bangalore Little Theatre was privileged to be invited to stage the opening shows of the play at the places hallowed by Gandhi and Tagore in their lifetime – Sabarmati Ashram, Santiniketan (Visva Bharati) and Jorasanko in Kolkata. The Kolkata performance was at the courtyard stage of Thakurbadi, the Tagore ancestral home, now a heritage site looked after by Rabindra Bharati University. On the occasion of Gurudev Rabindranath Tagore’s birth anniversary, the play was staged at the Raj Bhavan, Bangalore, with the President of India in attendance. Later, the play was performed by invitation in Dhaka and Chittagong, Bangladesh, as part of the India-Bangladesh Joint Celebrations of Tagore’s 150th birth anniversary. Prasar Bharati commissioned a tele-film of the play. The film was telecast several times over Independence Day and Gandhi Jayanti. There have been about 130 performances of the play since its opening. The play has generated much interestoutside India as well. It has had two American productions, one in Houston and the other at the University of Iowa. Productions in UK and Ireland are also planned. A highly successful tour of Trinidad & Tobago was followed by performances in Singapore, co-hosted by Tagore Society and the Indian High Commission. The play was invited to Sydney for celebrations of Gandhi’s 150th birth anniversary. An enriching experience ... Times of India, KolkataEnthralled ... President Pratibha Patil at Raj Bhavan A moving evening, elevating The Hindu, Bangalore Exalting and inspiring experience ... New Indian Express, BangaloreEnlightening ... melody from fascinating verbal images ... Times of India, Ahmedabad Powerful and enlightening ... The Star, Dhaka The audience thoroughly enjoyed every bit of this play ... a standing ovation ... Deccan Herald, Bangalore. Simply superb ... a rare non-fiction drama. Shunya Theatre, Houston Gandhi, Tagore leave Trinidad & Tobago spellbound ... Guardian, Trinidad. Highly educative, an extraordinary production ... Faculty, University of Chittagong Amazing presentation, outstanding performance ... Indian High Commissioner, Singapore Every Indian must see this play .... Prof. CNR Rao, Bharat RatnaInspiring history, beautifully presented ... Gerson daCunha A great message for today’s highly polarized world ... Indian Link, Sydney. Important history, beautifully recreated. India International Centre Truly inspiring presentation of important history ... Ashoka UniversityMoving and compelling ... Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad Greatly privileged to have this presented by a member of our founding faculty ... IIM Bangalore. Extraordinary presentation of very relevant history ... Dr. Souraja TagoreAbout Vijay PadakiVijay Padaki is a Theatre Educator based in Bangalore. He has worn two caps all his life with equal facility. He has been active in the theatre for over sixty years. He has been a management professional for over forty-five years.Vijay joined Bangalore Little Theatre in 1960, the year of its inception, and later served the company in many capacities – as actor, director, trainer, writer, designer and administrator. In 2008, Bangalore Little Theatre Foundation was restructured as a Public Charitable Trust. It was done with the purpose of reinforcing the organisation’s commitment to social development goals beyond performance. The Trust requested Vijay to provide the leadership to a newly-created Academy of Theatre Arts in its formative years.Age 16+

name: The Pleasure Circle with Nishtha Kaushik
description: Rediscovering desire, body and intimacy post-partumIntimacy shifts do not happen in isolation, and they definitely are not by design. They are a result of cultural norms and conversations that were not designed around women navigating motherhood.This facilitated, small-group circle is for mothers who want to reconnect with their desire, confidence, and connection without forcing it. We will talk about intimacy shifts like fatigue, body image, guilt, mental load, and explore practical ways of addressing them. The Pleasure Circle is rooted in honest conversation, guided reflection, and simple tools that support reconnection over pressure.About the facilitator:Nishtha is a marketer, trained dancer and somatic movement practitioner who focuses on intimacy and the pleasure gap women face. Over the past five years, she’s created spaces for women to explore desire, body image, and guilt in the US, UK and now, back home here in Bengaluru. Having grown up in India amid sexual taboos, she’s passionate about helping women reconnect with pleasure through honest conversation and embodied, guided practices.

name: Weaving A Story
description: Join us for a curated storytelling evening - Weaving a story. Whether you're a lover of textiles, history, or just fascinated by Indian heritage and Classical Dance, this event will wrap you in the magic of tradition.This event is organized in partnership with Janani Murali, renowned Bharatanatyam practitioner and Shruthi Kezhakepuram Purushotham, Mohiniyattam exponent.About Janani Murali: Janani Murali is a performer, researcher, educator and writer based in Bangalore who uses Bharatanatyam to access and address socio-cultural complexities. She trained under her mother, Guru Smt. Padma Murali, and serves as Associate Artistic Director of Padmalaya Dance Foundation and Executive Member of the International Dance Alliance, Bangalore Chapter. An A Grade artist of Doordarshan Kendra and empanelled artist of ICCR, Murali traverses traditional and contemporary formats of performance and dance education. Her work has earned titles including Nalanda Nrutya Nipuna, Padmavati Puraskar and Narthana Shironmani. Her work and research into “Creative Processes” under the UNBOXED series aims at using performing arts to add value in interdisciplinary environments. Murali is also a biologist with corporate experience in the pharmaceutical industry. She continues to publish clinical and medical research and holds leadership roles at Young Indians.About Shruti:Shruthi Kezhakepuram Purushotham is a distinguished traditional dancer renowned for her mastery and innovative approach to Mohiniyattam. Her work reflects a deep understanding of Indian traditional dance as a movement form enriched by its historical and regional roots. Shruthi's artistry uniquely blends contemporary themes and self-expression, making her performances timeless and relevant.About Aparna:Aparna Jaishankar is a Storyteller, Educator and Corporate Trainer.Aparna’s passion lies in exploring Indic Mythology with a contemporary lens. She enjoys the various versions of these stories found in the nooks and crannies of the Indian subcontinent in the form of songs, theatre, dance, weaving, rituals and practices. She incorporates these rich sources in her Storytelling performances.

name: That’s What She Said: Playback Theatre Performance
description: On the occasion of Women’s Day, we ask a simple question:Why should women be celebrated only on one day?Women are powerful, complex, and extraordinary every single day—yet too often treated like second-hand citizens the rest of the year. This performance begins right there, challenging the idea of limiting celebration to a date on the calendar.Instead, we open a space for real stories.Stories of being a woman.Stories of loving, learning from, and living alongside women.Stories of mothers, teachers, mothers-in-law, partners, sisters, daughters, friends, bosses, colleagues, daughters-in-law—and everything in between.Stories of how men see the women in their lives.Stories of embracing the feminine within.What to ExpectThis unique Playback Theatre experience invites the audience to share personal moments and lived experiences. In real time, our performers will transform these stories into spontaneous theatre using movement, music, and dialogue—honest, unscripted, and deeply human.Threads and Tales is an Applied theater initiative by Lahe Lahe Caravan ⏱️When: 8th March | 5:30 – 7:00 PM📍 Where: Atta Galata, Indiranagar🎟 Tickets: 300 rs per person

name: Zara Sa Yaad Rakhna Hai- An Evening of Ghazals
description: We scroll past everything.A war.A wedding reel.A protest.A discount code.Smoke over a city.A poem we almost read.And somewhere between all of it, our heart doesn’t get enough time to feel.Zara Sa Yaad Rakhna Hai is an evening of ghazals that refuses to hurry.Seven stories, seven moments we choose not to swipe past.From Ghalib’s unanswered wounds in Ibn-e-Mariamto Mir’s lingering question - Yeh dhuan kahan se uthta hai?from Faiz’s dignified defiance in Aaj Bazaar Meinto a deeply personal new composition being released that evening!this is not just a mehfil.It is a pause.With tabla, harmonium, electric guitar and voice, we sit with stories of loss, desire, forgiveness, protest, memory  and allow music to stretch time.In a world that rewards speed, come choose stillness.Scroll. Stop. Stay.

name: TPCC Recap: Heart of a Dog
description: “Heart of a Dog” is a Soviet film adaptation of Mikhail Bulgakov’s iconic novella. Set in 1920s Moscow, it tells the satirical and darkly humorous story of a stray dog named Sharik, who is transformed into a human by Professor Preobrazhensky through a daring medical experiment. The resulting man, Poligraf Poligrafovich Sharikov, embodies the social and ideological tensions of early Soviet society. With its sharp critique of class struggle, human nature, and the perils of radical change, the film is celebrated for its faithful adaptation, brilliant performances, and rich allegorical depth.

name: Creaturely Circles: Staying Alive to Inequality
description: If you are reading this, it is possible that you, like me, benefit in visible and invisible ways from the extractive economies of our time. This is not to blame and shame, for we are living within systems that were set up before us, shaped by forces larger than any one of us. Within such systems, it can feel easier to narrow our field of vision and focus on what seems within our control: our work, our families, our health, our immediate responsibilities.We were born into a world organized around winners and losers. When the scale of suffering far exceeds the scale of our agency, forging ahead on our own path can feel like the only viable option, instead of feeling weighed down by those who are losing. Numbness to inequality (particularly income inequality) can even present itself as clarity and pragmatism.All this, again, is not to shame the urge to look away; but to notice for ourselves when and where we might feel like we have agency rather than feeling numb when we encounter the kinds of deeply entrenched socio economic inequality we see around us.There are spaces for solutioning, but this is not one of them, for income inequality is not a problem that stands alone. It is a by-product of the extractive, complex systems we live in.Can we first stay present to the harms we are entangled in without going numb?This gathering is an invitation to explore that question together.

name: ​Get Started with Freelancing ​- 1 day workshop
description: Get Started with Freelancing​Build your freelance business in one day. Structure, tools, and a system that works.​The Problem​You want to freelance. You don't know what to charge, how to position yourself, or where to find clients.​Every tutorial gives you pieces. This workshop gives you the complete structure.​What You'll Build​In 6 hours, you'll create:​✅ 6 strategy documents - positioning, pricing, services, client qualification, marketing, portfolio✅ Your own AI business advisor - trained on your specific business✅ A live website - no-code, ready to share​This isn't just support. It's plug-and-play templates, playbooks, and a scalable model.​How It Works​Morning: The 6 Foundations​Work through 6 exercises using physical prompt cards. Upload your answers to Claude. Generate professional strategy documents.​Map it out. Price it out. Scope it out. Filter it out. Put it out. Build it out.​Afternoon: Build Your Tools​Create a custom AI advisor (ChatGPT or Claude) trained on your 6 documents. Launch your website using Antigravity. No coding required.​Who This Is For​You're not here to hustle harder - you're here to build smarter.​This workshop is for:​People with skills who don't know how to sell them​Anyone stuck on pricing, positioning, or packaging​Beginners who want structure, not guesswork​Anyone ready to use AI tools the right way​Whether you're starting fresh or scaling up, there's a place in this system for you.​What to Bring​Laptop (charged)​Basic idea of what you want to offer​Willingness to build​We provide the cards, templates, frameworks, lunch, and coffee.​Details​Date: Sunday, 15th February 2026Time: 10 AM - 4 PMLocation: Away Center, KoramangalaPrice: ₹699/-​Limited spots for hands-on support.​Quick Answers​No portfolio? We'll build your strategy anyway.Don't know AI tools? We'll teach you.Not sure what to offer? We'll help you figure it out.Working website by end of day? Yes.​AI is shifting work. We're shifting the system - with you at the center.​No fluff. No middlemen. Just the real stuff that moves you forward.

name: Emotional hygiene: The skill that no one taught us
description: Every day, we practise physical hygiene without thinking.We brush our teeth.We wash our hands.We clean our homes.Because we know small build-ups, if ignored, turn into bigger problems.But what about emotional build-up?The argument you replay.The message you overthink.The stress that lingers in your body.Emotional hygiene is learning how to clear these feelings before they pile up.It helps you notice what’s bothering you, calm your system, and let go — instead of carrying everything forward.So you don’t bring yesterday into today.So you respond, instead of react.So you feel lighter inside.Because peace isn’t accidental.It’s practised.This is an invitation to care for your inner world as intentionally as you care for everything else.

name: Ode to Broken Things: Book Launch
description: Join us to celebrate Shruti Kulkarni’s debut poetry collection and reading from her book Ode to Broken Things. The poet will be in conversation with Vinutha Mallya.Ode to Broken Things is a reflection on what it means to be human, to be a living repository of timestamps of our individual and collective struggles and celebrations and of rebellions and failures. These poems are a quiet observation of our responses to the passing of these events and of our efforts to understand this world that offers experiences of duality — of wars and peacetime, abundance and poverty, of love and hate. Ode to Broken Things is also a prayer and an earnest dream for a peaceful world for everyone, where all hearts are warm and borders are always open.In Ode to Broken Things, we are taken to the heart of matter — to observe the atomic, the molecular, the granular parts of our inner and outer worlds that we miss amid the unsettling busyness. Ode to Broken Things invites us to feel, see, think and wonder about all that surrounds us. Raw and uncut, these poetic expressions draw us towards hope. – Vinutha Mallya [Journalist, editor and lecturer]

description: Family Constellation CircleSome patterns are inherited. When what was unseen becomes visible, something begins to settle. Not by force. Not by analysis. But through recognition.This is not talk therapy. This is experiential.In a respectful, grounded circle, we explore the deeper layers beneath repeating patterns, unexplained heaviness, relational blocks, guilt, grief, anxiety, or feeling “stuck” despite doing inner work.Many participants share that what shifts is subtle yet unmistakable:A calmer nervous systemA sense of clarity that was missingEmotional release without reliving traumaA quiet understanding of “this makes sense now” Even those who attend as representatives or observers often experience personal insight and movement within their own lives.You may feel called to attend if you: Keep repeating similar relationship or emotional patterns.Carry guilt, fear, or heaviness without a clear reason.Feel blocked despite personal growth efforts.Sense that something older than you is asking to be acknowledged.﻿What to Expect: A safe, confidential group setting Guided facilitation with care and structureDeep yet gentle explorationNo prior knowledge or preparation requiredYou do not need to understand the process for it to workSometimes presence is enough.Link for pre-session questionaire for client

name: TPCC Recap: A Look at Wang Bing
description: Screening this day: Three Sisters - The masterful new documentary from Wang Bing is an intimate, observational portrait of a peasant family who eke out a humble existence in a small village set against the stunning mountain landscapes of China’s Yunnan province.Father and Sons - In 2010, while he was filming “Three Sisters” in the mountain of Yunnan province, Wang Bing met two teenagers, Yonggao and Yongjin, whose father, a stonemason, had gone to the city in the hope of finding work. Wang Bing met up with them again in 2014, when they had been reunited with their father after four years in Fumin. For about a month, Wang Bing filmed their daily lives in the single squalid room that was their home. The fixed camera recorded the micro-events that punctuated their days : their father leaving for work, the youngsters themselves waking up, breakfast time, in front of the television, etc.

name: Full Moon Sound Healing + Intention Setting
description: The full moon is a sacred moment to pause, slow down, and look within. It’s a time to reflect, let go of what no longer serves you, and notice what has come to light. By letting go, you make space for new energy, new intentions, and new possibilities, a time for release, gratitude, and gentle closure.In this gently guided session, we’ll move through:✨ Breathwork: To ground yourself and create space within.📝 Reflection + Intention Setting: To gain clarity and consciously set intentions moving forward in the new year.🌕 Letting Go Ritual: To lovingly release what’s holding you back and make space for new possibilities.🎶 Sound Healing: To soothe the nervous system and release stagnant energy.Together, we’ll create a space for deep connection with yourself, your intentions, and the energy of new beginnings.Come as you are, and allow yourself to soften into this moment of self-care and renewal.About the FacilitatorSneha is a sound healer, mindfulness guide, and someone who’s walked the path from burnout to inner clarity. After years in the corporate world as a CA, I made an intentional shift, from spreadsheets to sound bowls, from deadlines to deep presence. Life gave me the courage to tune into my inner wisdom, and that led me here- to the path of healing, mindfulness, and holding space for othersToday, I blend sound healing, mindfulness, and psychology to help people feel more grounded, present, and connected to themselves. My work is heart-led, real, and rooted in everything I have experienced & learnt along the way.

name: In Her Interest by Zerodha (Investing 2.0 + AI)
description: Women have a complicated relationship with money.And it starts early.Many families shield their daughters from anything related to ‘finance’. This well meaning protection ends up being a disservice. For when these young women step into the real world, they lack the confidence to make financial decisions - not because they’re incapable, but because they were never given information on budgeting, savings and investments.Later in life, many continue to rely on their partners for investment decisions. This dependency on others will only stop when they have the right information and toolkit to take back control.That’s is where we come in.Our upcoming session is a safe, private space - where no question is too small or too basic.We’ll be focusing on one core idea:Building financial security for women through investing.The session at Bangalore will be led by two amazing experts who truly get it and will help you understanding investing better.Satya Sontaman -Chartered Accountant, Zerodha VarsityHansi Mehrotra - Chartered Financial Analyst and Founder The Money HansKey topics we’ll cover:Philosophy of MoneyActionable Money FrameworkUnderstanding the Money HouseFinancial Planning & Goal SettingAsset AllocationInvestment Products (Fixed Income, Equities, Mutual Funds)Active vs Passive InvestingInvestment Strategies & DiversificationCommunity ResourcesPLUSA session on how to work with AI - this is a session for beginners who want to create products (like money trackers etc) without code.(As women, we need to address the elephant in the room - AI, or we're going to be left behind. People who understand and learn to work with AI will be more employable in the future. Once you buy your ticket, you also have the option of sending in your question in advance, the speakers address all these questions through the session - so send them in :)

name: udal / osai
description: About the event:A work-in-progress sharing of a collaborative performance project created by Abhinaya- a dance practitioner from New Delhi, and Sasikumar- a Kattaikkuttu artist and Mukavinai player from Kanchipuram. Mukavinai is a wind instrument primarily used in Kattaikkuttu, a traditional form of musical theatre practiced in Tamil speaking rural regions. It is used as a mood and ambience enhancer with its melodic interventions, and as a supporting instrument for the performers and chorus in its present context. Abhinaya and Sasikumar have been exploring different genres of melody and movement, to see the diverse ways in which the body can meet the sound, and all the different spaces (physically and aurally) the mukavinai and the body can occupy together.The first phase of this project was supported by the Department of Performing Arts at Ashoka, and was developed over a short period of time at Kattaikkuttu Sangam in Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu.Tickets Mandatory for all.*

name: Movie Under the Stars | Beetlejuice (1988)
description: Join us for an open-air screening of Beetlejuice (1988). This delightfully strange, darkly comic cult classic celebrates the wonderfully eccentric brilliance of Catherine O’Hara, paired with a cosy three-course dinner by Chef Rhea Aaron and fresh popcorn under the stars.*Wines and other beverages will be available for purchase at the venue.*About the movie:Directed by Tim Burton, Beetlejuice follows the recently deceased Maitlands as they attempt to haunt the new inhabitants of their home, only to accidentally unleash a chaotic, mischievous bio-exorcist who turns their afterlife upside down.At its heart, the film is a playful ode to individuality, theatricality, and the joy of embracing the bizarre, brought to life most memorably through Catherine O’Hara’s iconic, eccentric portrayal of Delia Deetz. Equal parts outrageous and endearing, her performance adds a layer of stylish absurdity that makes the film endlessly rewatchable. Whimsical, visually striking, and unapologetically offbeat, it’s a perfect evening for those who love cult cinema, character-driven brilliance, and a little gothic humour.Paired with a thoughtfully prepared three-course dinner by Chef Rhea Aaron and wines from Wine in Progress, it’s an easy, feel-good way to spend a night outdoors, immersed in film, flavour, and a touch of eccentric magic.Terms and ConditionsThe management is not responsible for any injury or damage that may occur during the event.No liability or claims arising from the consumption or intake of any food or drink will be entertained by the management.Parking near the event premises is at the risk of the vehicle owner.Limited Valet service is available at a charge of Rs. 200 per vehicle.Photographs and videos of ticket holders may be uploaded to social media.
